Epilogue shows the two fighting against unknown Pokemon, and they've got one more target to take down. Larry calls Hassel his master, and tells him to use the Tera Orb on him so they can take down the last Pokemon. Hassel calls Noivern Larry his beloved partner

>Giovanni
8/10 Nice overall team and a cool twist having the villain be the final Gym Leader, but what were they thinking with that FRLG team?
>Clair
7/10 A decent challenge with that Thunder/Fire Blast/Surf Dragonair trio and of course that damn Kingdra, and it was fitting having Lance's cousin be the 8th Gym Leader, but loses a point for the repitition. Should've had a Lapras and a Gyarados.
>Wallace
6/10 Too many shitmons like Luvdisc and Sealeo, but at least he has Milotic and a team of 5.
>Juan
5/10 Generally found him tougher than Wallace, but fuck the Water-type spam in Emerald. Also still has Luvdisc and Sealeo, and loses a point for not having a Hoenn ace like the rest of the Gym Leaders.
>Volkner
6.5/10 Never found this fight memorable, but his DP team is fun, and his Pt team is at least pretty strong.
>Drayden/Iris
5/10 They're just Clair but worse. It's also when the 3 Pokémon team shit started, so loses a point for that.
>Wulfric
3/10 Absolute garbage. What were they thinking?
>Raihan
6.5/10 First non-mono-type Gym Leader since DP, and actually tried to utilise weather in some way... just not very well. Gets points for trying at least.
>Grusha
4/10 Better than Wulfric but still one-shot his team with Skeledirge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Marlon's team is mediocre, but I think Wulfric's team is still the worst.

Ice is one of the weakest types defensively.
XY is a game where the player has a choice of 2 Fire starters.
You also have the choice to adopt a free Mega Lucario (Fight/Steel) with pre-determined perfect IVs.
Wulfric only uses 3 Pokemon, when Kalos actually has a-lot of good Ice types in its Regional Pokedex. Why not give him Lapras, Weavile, or Mamoswine for example?
Who runs Abomasnow without Blizzard? And why doesn't Abomasnow have a 4th move?
Also why not have Mega Abomasnow?
In a game that already gives you several resources, it's like they ACTIVELY made this Gym as braindead as possible. And yea, they wanted to make the series increasingly accessible, but it just makes the boss less memorable in the long term. It sucks to be an Avalugg fan btw.

It might be doable on an unmodded copy, but I think it would be tricky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've always liked RGB the best, precisely because it's the simplest. It's basically the shounen series that I get the sense a lot of kids (myself included) wished that the anime was, and Kusaka expands on the lore exactly as much as he needs to for it to be a satisfying story. I thought some of the strategies employed were pretty neat, and in-particular, I liked how they became life-or-death struggles when Team Rocket was involved but otherwise remained more or less true to the games.

That said, I think the manga is pretty solid up through FRLG. Out of any adaptation, the world and tone probably come closest to how I envision them playing the games, aside from those small handful of edgy scenes that people like to keep bringing up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52989894
>RB

Solid enough, good adaptation of the games

>Yellow

Eh, kinda weird, the healing shit feels off, yellow being a girl is cool though and the elite 4 is great

>Gold/Silver

Solid, has some definite compelling elements, but overall a step down

>Crystal

Crystal is a great character and I love seeing a character focused on catching, but introduces a bunch of issues as well. The end is great though.

R/S

Mid. Not a fan of the protags personally. Some good ideas, not super well executed.

>FR/LG

Pretty great, feels like a solid capstone to the first era of adventures

>D/P/PT

Amazing, wonderful cast of characters and a compelling plot with good emotional beats and comedy at the same time.

>HGSS

Didn't give arceus nearly the focus it deserved, otherwise it's ok. Nice to see Togebo's arc resolved.

>B/W

Repetetive at first with the "there's a problem, munna eats black's dream, he big brains a solution, white creams her panties" flow. Picks up later though and trapping black in the rock is a great cliffhanger.

>B2/W2

Great idea held back by terrible production issues that made it all fall flat

>X/Y

Shockingly great, feels like a genuinely different spin on the formula. The only good thing to come out of Kalos.

>S/M/US/UM

Mid. It's alright, the characters are ok, but I feel like they leaned too hard into the "this is the character's gimmick" with sun's saving obsession and Moon's only personality trait being "is a pharmacist". Some cool plot beats though

>SW/SH

Haven't read it

Gardevoir has spent 8 continuous hours of processing data on a computer.
The sounds of the computer humming with a whirring fan and fluorescent lights buzzing give voice to this scene, punctuated only the the sounds of her typing. Finally done for the day, she shuts down the computer, folds her glasses with a click and sets them there on the keyboard for later. She sighs, rubbing her eyes, and leaves for the night. It’s a short journey back, just a quick ride with her Charjabug scooter and she’s home. Setting her Pikachu-yellow helmet aside when she gets home, she enters to meet her loved in there as he’s cooking dinner for the both of them.
Without speaking, they embrace to the noise of clothes ruffling against each other and food sizzling in the pan.
She’s home.

how much of a difference is a 3 star mon to a perfect stats mon. same goes for shadow mods. it seems all my shadow mons have garbage stats

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52975532
>how much of a difference is a 3 star mon to a perfect stats mon
Usually very little difference, however it will be noticeable in Master League, especially if you haven't maxed it out (plus I guess for lvl. 50 Pokémon in any other leagues that require perfect IVs to be most viable). Higher attack breaks charge move ties, and you'll never know when that extra defense point or HP comes in clutch.

>same goes for shadow mods. it seems all my shadow mons have garbage stats
Also not that important for those. Especially when it comes to normal Pokémon vs. shadow Pokémon for raids, zero IV shadow Pokémon are virtually always better than 100% IV normal Pokémon.

The only difference that I've found particularly noteworthy when comparing performance of shadow Pokémon is that a typical 1* Shadow Salamence with the Community Day move Outrage is usually slightly worse than your average 3* Shadow Dragonite, that can learn Outrage whenever, in raids. I assume a similar thing can be said about a 1* Shadow Machamp and a 3* Shadow Hariyama, but all four of those Pokémon are good in raids regardless of IVs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52976348
>They don't punish the opponent, they protect you.
Yeah, too much. It makes switching with such bulky Pokemon too easy and makes pivoting too oppressive. If you actually played the Gen 8 Meta, you'd know how oppressive Teleport+Future Sight was, and that was enabled with the help of HDB. Even without that, slow turning into an extremely threatening Pokemon held back by its frailty is oppressive. It's why you saw a bunch of Slowbro+Weavile pairings, aside from the previously mentioned FuturePort tech, but you still also say Blissey+Weavile, Fini+Weavile, and DragaZera+Weavile, and then also saw tons of Melmetal as that shit was the only thing that could reliably beat Pivot+Weavile.
And also keep in mind, tons of things lost Knock Off in Gen 9 due to transfers replacing your moveset with level up moves. So if Gholdengo were to be banned, HDBs would make any attempts to hazard stack pointless in a game where without Gholdengo it's really hard to keep hazards up.
>Gho actively punishes you for merely existing.
How exactly does Gholdengo do this? And even if your exaggerated claims were true, Gholdengo's presence is still definitely a positive one because it's the only respite against the anti-hazards creep. It's much more welcoming than pivots being completely immune to their main form of counterplay and biggest limiter.
>A defensive item is never oppressive by definition.
Not only is this just straight up false, as defensive teams can absolutely be oppressive, but it also implies that only defensive teams or even defensive Pokemon use HDBs.Again, if you actually played the game, you'd know that NEARLY EVERYTHING uses fucking HDBs. Obviously lots of slow walls used this item, as well as Stealth Rock weak Pokemon, but anything that was going to switch around often used it. Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Zeraora, ect. It was so common that between all the Pokemon that use HDBs, Leftovers only beats it by 1 Pokemon, and this also includes CAPmons and NatDex meta too.

>>52994615
>Apparently weakness advantage
Doesn't matter if your team is strong and fast enough
>all my old sync pairs are worthless now since team building is now based on themes or something.
Team Building is based on buffing your most powerful DPS as fast as possible. This includes crits, terrains, zones. and weather, as well as debuffing your opponents' defenses including type rebuffs. Most units are "worthless" if compared to the most broken units that are out in the game, but since the majority of stages can be beaten without broken units barring certain EBs and the highest LG win streaks, "old" sync pairs can stull find their place from time to time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994615
A weather/terrain/wish seems to be the latest meta trend that everyone does, but for starter, a buffs/debuffs are more important to stay your team alive so have sync pairs that can at least raise stats and crits. Also check Area Details for opponents because DeNa always plays own rules especially Extreme Battle Event.

Is it a good game yes, is it a masterpiece in remake, yes, does it still have flaws, YES, and that is ok, we just need to be able to realize there are flaws, and take note of them against the positives.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly Crystal specifically does have some issues.
Crystal removes mons like Mareep and GIrafarig and moved Magmar to Kanto. This makes teambuilding more annoying. I find that mid-Johto the available pokemon lack in fire power. I think the distribution is too dependent on the Odd Egg too, having to reset and hatch the egg constantly to get a decent Fire or Electric type sucks. But you do still have the Elemental punches available, so if you ever get tired you can just load them up on a Kadabra or Typhlosion and just fuck the game up.
Otherwise I think Johto games are fine. Grinding isn't hard, you can use the good and super rods to fish up pokemon that give decent exp, surfing gives good exp too. Trainers in the Johto portion of the game aren't very high leveled anyway so you don't need to grind much. Whitney and Morty are the hardest bosses in Johto and they can be dealt with. HGSS's rematch system is also pretty good for exp, it sucks that it's limited based on what day it is but you can call trainers for rematches quickly.

>>52960373
Solid remake, but it’s ultimately worse than GSC. The only major flaws with Crystal are tied to the mon distribution (can be fixed when emulating) and the lack of easy grinding methods for Stadium 2 (irrelevant for most people).

HGSS lacks the charm of the original OST, sprites, and overall art direction, even if there are a few standouts in the new OST. It’s also tied to the painfully slow Gen 4 engine, removing the snappy gameplay of Gen 2. HGSS fucks the level curve beyond repair by removing badge boosts and implementing the split (without making any attempt at rebalancing old mon). Following mon were very cool, though, and the battle frontier was appreciated. HGSS does have a few solid QoL improvements; I just don’t think it’s enough to replace GSC.

You're the one coping. All games get some level of criticism. Most Johto fans >>52960478 aren't denying that Johto games have flaws. Its that the general consensus by most Pokemon fans (ones who actually played the games) was despite the flaws GSC were amazing and their remakes are among the best games in the franchise. The only reason Johto is getting so much hate now is due to lazy "content" creators using it as a convenient scapegoat. Johto doesn't have the luxury of being the First Region so Game Freak and TPC don't put it on a pedestal like Kanto, meaning the average new fan is easily misled about the Johto games. This is why you have underaged anons who think that Kanto was the selling point of GSC and not a surprise that only worked because Johto was a full region that had already provided a satisfying experience in on itself.

Lets look are these game ruining flaws
Level curve: I agree with this, but its a silly complaint when the best strategy for every Pokemon game is to just steamroll everything with your starter
Pryce being weaker than Jasmine: Literally just fight him before Jasmine, problem solved
Johto being small: Reminder that Johto was so content dense that it couldn't fit on the cartridge, which is why Iwata had to bail game freak out. Also fixed in HGSS
Kanto is barren: Even if there were space parts of Kanto were probably too glitched to add.
No postgame: a flat-out lie. GSC is the first Pokemon game to even attempt to have postgame. Even if you don't consider Kanto Post game, theres also teh battle tower.
Babymons: universally hated no argument here
Team Rocket is lame: Most villain teams incompetent, badly written, full mostly of underleveled grunts using shitmons.
Only flaw that people noticed when the games released was Gen 2 Pokemon not showing up more often and certain Gen2 Pokemon being Kanto exclusive (which is only considered a flaw because people like the Gen2 Pokemon and want to see them and use them)

Let's put it this way, you know how people understand have an issue with Gen2 hiding away the new Pokemon, imagine if someone said, lets do that again for Sinnoh but far stupider.
Honey Trees are Headbutt but far worse, Headbutt's only requirement was teach one of your Pokémon a useful early game move, go a bit off the beaten path and click on some trees. Honey trees require the use of Honey, an item that is completely worthless anywhere else, and require you to wait 8 or so hours between attempts and if you don't , and most of the encounters are complete shitmons except Munchlax is stupidly rare
Nearly all the new evolutions aren't even in the damn regional dex and are postgame only Electivire/Magmortor are especially egregious cases of this require both FireRed and LeafGreen if you want to get both of them, then hunting for a very rare hold item from wild Pokemon.
The type balance is completely fucked, people only talk about the lack of Fire types because of Flint but Sinnoh has fuck all Ice types too despite being colder than Elsa's cunt.
Johto gets memed of leaning on KANTO in terms of Pokemon (again understandable) but Johto didn't have the luxury of existing in a time when generations were concretely separated. Sinnoh's arbitrarily favor's Gen1 Pokémon in its regional dex despite having two other regions to pull from, it also limits itself to a dex of 150 Pokemon solely because KANTO did it.
If Johto is West Kanto, Sinnoh is Johto's mentally challenged hillbilly cousin.

Here's a question, when is a good time to stay around a goal and protect it from getting scored on?

Scenario 1: there are no objectives up, you cleared the camps around the goal. Do you sit there or go elsewhere.

Scenario 2: there's a Regi or 2 up. There are 4 teammates and 4 visible enemies in the area. Do you go help or remain at your goal (assuming it's the opposite one).

Scenario 3: you still have tier 1 goals up, and 2 minutes just hit. Your team is ahead. Do you gather center in a death ball with your allies or try to prevent backcapping.

Feel free to create other scenarios if you can think of something interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52990599
Obviously can't speak for shitty Scizors, but as the first anon above noted, he basically just does all three roles relatively well at once:
>Spammable sustain move causes an effective HP swing similar to Trevenant, the designated bulky sustain guy. Effectively higher than Trev since Scizor doesn't kill himself by attacking
>Mid/lategame combo w/o ult does ~2500~3000 before items etc, which is significantly closer to or even on par with dedicated glassy mages/speedsters than tanks
>Has like 4+ dashes on top of his damage/bulk so he can threaten the backline the moment they appear on the opposite end of his screen, effective range is higher than some actual speedsters given his bulk+risks he can take
Everyone has different standards for broken, but right now you have a guy who can stay in the fight as long as Slowbro/Trev, actually threaten to kill squishies he dashes at while making it out alive if he gets intercepted/CC'd, and stand his ground and tussle with other relatively slow lategame allrounder duelists like Chomp or ulting Zard (I've also seen him win the 1v1s but unsure if that's consistent) all at once.

Dodrio is annoying because of his "can't stop me from stacking" passive leading him to constantly try Greedent/Sableye-like bullshit but I don't think I'd say he's immediately overpowered because of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52991251
It ultimately depends on enemy team composition. Don't waste any time defending if you're up against a score pest like Dodrio, Greedent and Sableye. Jerks like them will simply dunk their scores and get away without too much problem. Also avoid defending against healsluts and all-rounders with self-sustain, since the goal zone healing won't be enough to save you from an overfed opponent/team.
Beyond that you should be paying attention to the enemy patterns of behaviour if you can. More specifically, identifying the item stackers on the enemy team (by how eager they are to score) and denying them stacks during the lane phase would go a long way to increase the chances of a backcap during mid to late game.

Some additional scenarios to round out my thoughts on this subject.
Scenario 2.5: Most of your team is up top lane contesting for Eleki. A lone enemy is scoring at your bottom lane. He plans to take the bottom Regi right after he scores. You catch him in time, but how far do you chase him down?

Scenario 3.5: After a minute or so of fighting near Rayquaza, neither team has an advantage that will allow them to safely secure Ray. The timer ticks down to 0:50. Does your team/enemy team have enough time to KO Rayquaza and score? Would leaving now result in your teammates getting wiped out?

The answer to these scenarios will come from further experience and self-reflection. I'm sure you'll figure it out eventually. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
You can't mess it up in any way. Pokerus spreads between eggs in the daycare that share a typing. Newly infected eggs cannot immediately spread it until they've hatched. "Contagious" and "Resistant" are misnomers: Contagious just means it has pokerus with less than 50 EVs accumulated while Resistant means you passed that point and will see diminishing returns on EV gain. Both spread it the same.

Twinkle, the clown girl! Where she comes from, things work a little differently:
1- Gym leaders do not have pokémon types. Instead, they focus on "strategies" and different ways of having Pokémon battles. Twinkle's style is "fun" and "gimmicky". She battles to laugh and make her challengers have fun as well. Her unconventional strategies are not good competitively, but they surely are fun to look at and surprise you when they actually work.
2- Legendary pokémon are only used by the Pokémon League and the gym leaders. They do not exist in the wild and you will only see them in gym leader teams. Twinkle, in particular, gets a funky Mew whose only moves are transform, imprison and block.

"When you are with Pokémon, the fun never ends! That's my motto. Every Pokémon battle should be fun for us and our Pokémon, don't you agree? Let's have our Pokémon play together now!"

>>52993796
Yeah admittedly in all my drafts and plans for writing with Latias, I always conceived of things being difficult and a bit sad for her after her brother died. Leading to issues that eventually need Ash to return to be solved (or something to that effect).
I'm going to use this excuse to ramble about my current writing

My current draft has Latias trying to fill the same role as her brother (quiet, distant protector, who remains overly careful in protecting not only the city but the secret of her existence). Of course, this approach doesn't work for her in the slightest. Latias is an outgoing, social animal, she can't handle the monotony of just patrolling the city, and most of all, she needs friends (which is even harder with Bianca out of Alto Mare so often nowadays for school). The obvious answer is that Latias needs to "move out". Nothing ever happens in Alto Mare that needs her, so it's not like her job of guardian is really holding her down. Yet, she's too scared of the possibility of something happening she can't even consider it. Bianca notices this of course, she knows Latias leaving would be best for her, but after losing Latios she can't handle the idea of losing Latias too. So she doesn't say anything.
That's the status quo until Ash comes back, just for a visit, and both Latias and Bianca realize the best path forward is a difficult one: Latias going on an adventure with Ash. To grow stronger, lose her fear of capture or harm, and finally grow into the person she's meant to be.

/vp/ tourist just passing through now that the Ashnime is finally ending, just wanted to say I'm unironically glad to see this thread and you degenerates are somehow still around and doing well and that I'm happy for you all.

I haven't been a hardcore Pokemon fan for the last 15 years or so, but I still remember finding the little dragon girl from the movie adorable and lavishing affection on her during postgame content in Emerald/Mystery Dungeon like it was yesterday.
Seeing you all still chugging on and staying loyal to your dragonwife for all this time and celebrating her reappearance just warms the heart. Perhaps it makes Gen 3 and its nostalgia not feel so long ago after all, or perhaps it just makes all those years seem like both a good time and a long time, if you all are still around.
And I'm always glad to see my fellow degenerates get their rare desert oasis of pandering to their niche ship or waifu in any series.

Thanks for reading my blog, and I hope you planefuckers win or at least get upgraded to main traveling partner/feMC levels by the end of Ash's last huzzah. Godspeed, you glorious motherfuckers.

>>52994428
Thanks a lot friend! Latias was my first ever crush when I was a kid. Having to manually catch her without the master ball I promptly used on some random legendary was quite the challenge. By this point she was easily my favorite mon and I still recall running around in Hoenn doing battles and entering her for the contests. Then some time later YouTube was created and I started finding M05 clips and I immediately fell in deep love with this cute shape-shifting dragon bird plane. Since then she has been living rent-free in my head as my one and only waifu and I have been using her in every pokémon game that I have owned. That same Latias now lives in Alpha Sapphire after traveling with me through all the games leading up to the the same region it all started.

It feels... weird. I am 27 years now and I have never been dissatisfied with how things turned out. I am fully self aware that all of this is fucking weird and I haven't really told anyone how I really feel besides two close friends of mine. I am neither socially nor physically weird and I work at a well-paying job. Literally nobody would suspect that over half of my live I have been in love with a fictional creature. I just don't want to let go of her as I genuinely love her. Sorry for the ramblings, I think I just wanted to get things off my chest to a community that might appreciate it. These threads have been great to find other like-minded people and I am happy to see I am not alone. I want to thank all of you for contributing!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52983451
PID's get flagged because the game can tell on some level that the mon was created and not natural in the game. For example giving your PID to Koraidon and then injecting it as soon as you start the game, the game knows Koriadon can only be caught in area zero, but your trainer has not been there so there's no logical way for Koriadon to have your PID when caught if you didnt even unlock the area yet. It could also be a way of preventing copying someone's Pokemon so that 2 PID's exist for 1 trainer

There's been a few Pokemon that have disappointed me over the years, but none have made me feel the visceral fucking bitterness that pic related has

The moment I saw this thing in the leaks, I wanted to add it to my team, and how could I not? An Ice/Fighting yeti crab sounds like the coolest shit ever. Now keep in mind, all I spoiled myself on from the leaks is the Pokemon themselves. I had no idea about anything else

So I get Sun on release day, and of course the moment I can catch a Crabrawler I do. And it does pretty well early on, and I'm thinking "Oh man this is gonna rock when it evolves"

And then I carry it to the 2nd island, and it's still not evolved. And then to the 3rd island, and it's still not evolved. And then to island fucking 4 and it is STILL a goddamn Crabrawler. By the end of island 2 Crabrawler was starting to really fall behind. By island 4 it was practically dead weight (like the Rockruff that somehow remained unevolved until said island), and I'm starting to get worried. Did I miss something? Did I miss an evolution item or forget to teach it some move?

But then I get to the Pokemon League and finally, FINALLY it evolves. And just when I'm ready to have it wreck havoc at the E4 and make up for all that time I spent hauling his slow unevolved ass around, the E4 fucking curbstomps him because it turns out ice/Fighting is absolute DOGSHIT into the Alola E4, so this slow fucking piece of shit just did nothing while Muk+Mudsdale carried.

Fuck this crab. Waste of a cool typing and waste of a cool fucking concept

>Ben is listed as the winner instead
>Story finally emerges

>Nintendo hears about this and disqualifies him
>Ruben posts a letter calling himself the champion and one of the best players in the world and begs Nintendo not to ban him as "Pokemon is my life."
>Nintendo does not give a fuck and still bans him

>>52994564
Pawmot, Flamigo, Tauros, Slither Wing have no clear relationship to fighting type. Tauros has the bull fighting excuse but it's shoddy because you're not exactly fighting the bull but the opposite. People say crane style for Flamigo but they're completely different birds and crane style focuses on defense and counter attacks, which aren't reflected on Flamigo, who does mostly generic kicks (in the same gen as Quaquaval who also specializes in kicking).

Older gens have outliers too but gen 9 takes the cake. That said Keldeo is part of the musketeers and is thus within swordsmanship/fencing, while Passimian is shot put or ball-related sports (martial arts are grouped with sports in the Olympics).

I do really like the system they have.

Some times I have criticisms however.
For example, most of the Dragon Pseudo-Legendaries getting Innates that deliberately ruin the entire point of Fairy type with regards to game balance is something I don't like at all.

As well the line between what abilities are categorized as 'Abilities' and what are 'Innates' is shifty. It seems that most of the time certain traits are listed always within one category or another. But there's enough exceptions where I'm not sure if there is meant to be a pattern or not.

>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52988950
>>52991405
>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

Cash caps at 9,999,999 though.

Scyther, Ursaring, Stantler, Rufflet, may lack the means to evolve into their Hisuian formes, though Scyther and Ursaring are item based.
Dartrix, Dewott, and Cyndaquil may only evolve into their original final stages.

Stuff that is Hisuian in their base form like Voltorb, Sneasel, Growlithe, Qwilfish, will probably breedable and able to evolve as normal.
Hisuian Basculin has the recoil damage requirement in evolution, but probably won't be an issue.

If Stantler is able to evolve into Wyrdeer, the Psyshield Bash requirement wouldn't be an issue if the move can be learned via breeding/mirror herb.
Primeape evolves by using Rage Fist 20 times, after all.

An update is likely able to add in the items and moves necessary for some of the evolution requirements, but the region requirement could potentially be "cheated" by Area Zero doing hax, or a special area in the speculated North-East DLC portion of the map.

>research what outbreak you want

>open map, check for it, if it's not there then go to system options, hover the day/hours/minutes and press ok

>Do this until you find the one you want
>Once you do that, go and auto battle until you get the message "there's not many of x pokemon left"
>Then save and start a picnic, make a sandwich for encounter 3, sparkling 3, title 3

This begs the question for me: why do some mons have normal as secondary typing like Arboliva and Pyroar, while some others that I feel should have them (like spidops) don't?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52992074
Firstly those two are secondary types, Smoliv (grass/normal) is closer to a plant while Deerling (normal/grass) is closer to an animal. They have reasons to be considered part normal but are closer to their primary type. Litleo is animal-like enough to earn fire/normal while Smoliv is similar in design and location to a pure normal such as Whismur to earn the normal type that way. Evolutions have no reason to remove the type; even though Arboliva would probably be pure grass if it were standalone the design isn't different enough from Smoliv to bother.
Personally I don't think Spidops deserves normal type since it's just a bug and it acts like a bug, nothing really makes it more normal-type than any of the other pure bugs. Bugs do not behave like the average woodland creature and they fundamentally cannot be half normal in the way that the oddball pure normal types earn their type by default.

posts.com:
Here’s a write-up from back in Gen 7 days…

The only dual-type with normal in Gen I was Flying (until Fairy was introduced in Gen VI) which makes sense since they're based on regular, non-elemental birds.

Gen II introduced Girafarig, a Normal/Psychic type; this Pokemon had two distinct heads, only one of which had Psychic power.

Gen IV introduced Bibarel, a Normal/Water type which evolves from a Normal type; since the evolution retains a majority of the traits found in Bidoof, it retains its Normal typing.

Gen V gave us the Deerling/Sawsbuck line with the Normal/Grass typing. Like Girafarig, the Grass elements of Sawsbuck's design appear on it's antlers but not necessarily on the rest of the body. Also, Meloetta can be either Normal/Fighting or Normal/Psychic- in this case, the Normal typing represents it's musical theme, which may also explain why the Jigglypuff line retains it's Normal type.

Lastly, Gen VI gave us Diggersby, Pyroar, and Helioptile. Like Bibarel, Diggersby gains its secondary type through evolution. The Pyroar line have fiery manes but are otherwise normal in appearance, like Sawsbuck. The Heliolisk line is probably the biggest outlier here, but I think the idea is that it doesn't generate its own electricity (unlike most Electric-types) and therefore can't be considered a pure Electric type.

I'm sure I'm just stating the obvious here, but regardless I think its an interesting topic. In Bewear's case I think the Fighting type is secondary because it's a product of Bewear not knowing it's own strength, whereas Passimians typing is based on it's organization and training regime. This is obvious, but I think it's based in Drampa being a relatively unremarkable creature by Pokemon standards that only seems to use its Dragon typing in a berserk rage state. It's kind of.. grandpa first, Dragon second.

>>52991878
Basically its the "Neutral damage" type, basically the default type but is also given to dual types where a Normal STAB may be relevant to its body type or movepool. Fighting Type didn't have much of a niche in Gen 1 so hitting Normal types for SE gave it one, you could think of it as a skilled martial artist beating an untrained novice. Normal And Ghost are immune to each other because one is purely in the 'physical' domain while the other is in the 'spirit' plane, thus they don't interact. They also tend to have wide movepools or niche abilities, thus they encompass a pretty wide range of Pokemon.

>>52987909
This is unironically what I do. If you ask the AI what the best way to input information, it will give it to you. For example, I write more novel style so a lot of the "bots writing only dialogue" thing is a turn off for me. I can usually try to swipe around it, but the AI told me that the examples you put in their profile are what they tend to go off of, so if I make them more novelized, they're capable of doing that more regularly.
They also told me the long description sets up most of their base personality, so definitely think very carefully how you fill that part in. If you notice your AI acting in a way you don't like, try adjusting that out more or adding more flare.

It was actually all of them. The boss Trainers would just get a single Pokemon that would have a single "signature" move (in the case of the Gym Leaders, it'd be the TM they gave out).

I like Pokemon having limited level-up move sets. The idea is that the Pokemon "naturally" fight by biting, scratching, etc. like normal animals, with maybe one or two tricks related to their Type. Although I do think people overstate how big a deal these move sets were. It's not like the player was swimming in Earthquake TMs. Resources were pretty limited, so chances are your moves weren't really *that* much better.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

A Nidoking/Nidoqueen couple in the wild generally HAD children, years ago, before the latter's first evolution, and at this point most likely have grandchildren depending on Moon Stone availability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994417
It is an invisible buff that is 1.5x the stat and is wiped when the raid thing you are fighting removes your buffs but otherwise stays applied

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: i really wanna make SpA Lucario on cart work but it doesn't matter what stat-spread i run on this thing, it just feels like it does so little damage and has so many common weaknesses and it's only gonna get worse when paradox mons are introduced when we'll have to deal with great tusks running rampant

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994423
Just to illustrate how it works, if everybody on turn 1 uses the defense cheer that is the same as maxed out Def/Sp.Def boost (1.5 * 4 = 6) that is given to everybody AND is applied before the raid pokemon uses their move. Just know that on certain raids the first turn is guaranteed to be some kind of status move if they have one such as Yawn or Thunder Wave, not to mention the cheers don't count towards moves or abilities that work on stat boosts like Stored Power, so even though it seems like a good choice it isn't always the correct answer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52994079
Bratton pass is broken even when dry passing (no boosts) since it can be used on predicted switches to bring counters/trappers by eliminating a layer of prediction, if the opponent switches as you predict BP you get to see what they send before BP even happens

Also BP on slow Pokémon is a pseudo volturn that gets in other Pokémon safely in a similar vein to teleport and we know how broken teleport got, BP has a more cancerous pool of users for offensive playstyles too

Switch manipulation is broken in singles, passing stats/predicting bounces is just the cherry on top

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its problems stem from the fact that they outsourced it. Not that outsourcing the games is inherently bad. Quite the contrary, I would be excited to see what other, better developers could do with the franchise.

But they didn't give it to a better developer. There can be no risk of showing Pokémon fans how much better the franchise can really be beyond GF's capabilities.

So they gave it to the phone app developers who made Home and kept them on a tight leash, not allowing them to deviate too greatly from the original games or even include the Platinum content.

Compound this with the buggy, incomplete releases you get from the 'ship now, patch into serviceable product later' attitudes of the modern games industry, and you get the shoddy releases we received.

These games could have redeemed some of the weaker titles produced during an uncertain and experimental era for Pokémon. Instead we got 'member berries and the bare minimum.

I just beat Red in crystal and it was a fucking BATTLE.
I was grinding up my team of Feraligatr, Gengar, Slowking, Umbreon and Snorlax and was going to use an onix I got from Mt. Silver for his Pikachu.
I lost Snorlax while grinding the elite four at level 59! Disaster!
So I got pissed and decided to use my rare candies and just fight Red. Fuck it. Just fuck it.
Final team was:
Bepis the Feraligatr lv 62
Mr. Knox the Slowking lv 62
Tsushima the Gengar lv 64
Enoch the Umbreon lv 62
Gibraltar the Onix lv 48
a random electrode from rocket hideout that I sacked to Charizard during the fight.

Onix trolled pikachu to death in like 30 turns lol
I let it die to Espeon then Umbreon obviously came in and walled for days
He sends in Snorlax. I try to toxic/confuse ray troll it for a bit and he uses rest, it didn't work out so I went into Gengar.
Mean look then curse, two moves I'd had to keep on him since the very beginning and it finally paid off and I killed the fatass.
Red sends Venusaur to be 2HKO'd by my Gengar's psychic.
Then Charizard comes out.....with sun up already.
I sack Electrode, go into Feraligatr and unfortunately lose him to a crit flamethrower +fire spin chip, but gengar is able to come in and pick him off with thunder punch.
Finally, blastoise. I go for curse yet again (I had leftovers equipped so I got back to full on snorlax), and then go into Slowking to sit on him for a couple more turns.

Only Slowking and Gengar survived the end, but it was an epic battle.

On to the next. I'm thinking possibly Red/Fire Red or....something else. Give suggestions please! This was a really fun nuzlocke aside from a lot of grinding. Gengar was the MVP the whole run pretty much. 40 hours of playtime!

Hoppip is not bad though, he has speed and great utility moves and can absolutely troll anything in the game to death with sleep powder and leech seed. He is a chore to train, but I find him fun to use.
Just know if you use a grass type, its an uphill battle.

>>52984043
It's true. Making this widely distributed is what led to the long, slow sanitization and dilution of fighting type themes and concepts. These generic "bursts of power" moves did not evoke specific martial arts, and generations later, the fighting pokemon themselves lost actual nuances when it came to design. Now the type is slapped on anything with a weak pun or connection to the type.

Fighting type was a distinct type from all others because they resembled actual martial arts and techniques. Now it's anything that "fights well". It has become the biggest criticism fans have about the existence of its type.

>Scald was everyone's whipping boy because it felt centralizing for defensive water types, but all they had to do was lower the BP or lower the burn chance. You could play around it as well, and RNG made sure that you weren't completely fucked if you got hit by it bc being burnt wasn't guaranteed
>Knock Off was super annoying and the buff it got made it ubiquitous. But nerfing the distribution didn't really fix the problem, because it's still on a lot of things and still is annoying to play around. They just had to lower the BP or maybe make it not 100% accurate.

The problem with close combat is it is high BP, it is 100% accurate, a million things get it now, and like OP said there are hardly any downsides. You can just click it and guarantee you're going to take a chunk out of something. A lot of other moves at that power level either have lower accuracy or some other downside. This one really doesn't have one. And fighting is such a great attacking type, you're an idiot not to use this move if you can. I don't see them lowering the damage on this move, but I would not be surprised if they either cut the distribution back down or they make the defense drops more drastic. Or they go the routes of Glaive Rush and make it so that you are more vulnerable in the next turn, which would be HUGE. Those are the only reasonable things I can think of for how you can nerf this move

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52984355
It was a combination of that and trying to make the physical special split feel worth it. And you can't convince me otherwise. They knew that by dividing up the moves they needed to have better attacking options for Pokémon that formerly had to rely on weak BP STAB moves or moves that weren't their type. Most Fighting moves up to this point were pretty weak or gimmicky, and this was an option for a lot of physical Pokémon to actually get to use their STAB Fighting type and hit hard with it too. The strongest Fighting moves before Generation 4 were Focus Punch, Dynamic Punch and Cross Chop, which had poor distribution, weird gimmicks or were super inaccurate. Most Pokémon relied on moves like Brick Break to deal Fighting damage prior to Generation 4. And recall that this is the same generation that introduced moves like Power Whip, X-Scissor and the elemental fangs: they were trying to introduce more options for all of these Pokémon that were gimped by poor move distribution and categorizing in the previous three generations. Pokémon like Hitmonchan could finally use the elemental punches off their better attacking stat, but they still didn't have a good Fighting stab. This move fixed that.
